In SuperPower Mod, military units and world wonders require a certain amount of [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower to maintain. If you have abundant [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower, the [ICON_GOLD] Gold cost for purchasing units and buildings will be reduced due to the lower cost of labor value.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]1. The use of Manpower: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Building regular army units. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Building World Wonders.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]2. How to acquire Manpower: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Cities will provide lots of [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower, which is its main source. Cities with larger population sizes will provide more [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Engineer specialists in your cities will produce a small amount of [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower. (+2 [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower per Engineer) [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Some buildings with an icon of [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower will provide a small amount of Consumer Goods on their own. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]You may also acquire [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower from other civilizations by trading or allied city-states.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]3. The Global Effects of Manpower: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]If you have abundant [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower (more than [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]25[ENDCOLOR]), you will receive a discount for the [ICON_GOLD] cost for purchasing units and buildings according to the total number of cities you own (maximum -35%, can multiply with other effects). Here is the math: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]P= n/(c*2)*5 (round down by 5) [NEWLINE](P:the discount percentage of [ICON_GOLD] cost for purchasing units and buildings; n:the number of [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower you currently have; c: the total number of cities you own)
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For example, if you have [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]50[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_MANPOWER] Manpower and own 5 cities. You will receive a bonus of -25% [ICON_GOLD] cost for purchasing units and buildings (P=50/(5*2)*5=25).

In SuperPower Mod, after entering the Modern Era, the Electricity System will be functional. [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity is a very important resource in the late-game. A modern civilization cannot survive without enough power supply.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]1. The use of Electricity: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]City population size. Larger cities will consume more [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Almost every post-industrial building requires a certain amount of [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity to be built.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]2. How to acquire Electricity: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Power Plants buildings (with an icon of [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY]) is the only source of [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity. Be aware that most of the Power Plants buildings will cause Pollution to the city which slow down the population growth. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]You may also acquire [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity from other civilizations by trading or allied city-states.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]3. The Global Effects of Electricity:
[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]If the number of [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity is negative (lower than [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]0[ENDCOLOR]), you will receive [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science penalty by percentage (maximum -50%[ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output nationwide) according to the total number of cities you own. Here is the math: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]P= n*(c/10) [NEWLINE](P:the additional percentage of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science penalty caused by the number of negative [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity; n:the number of negative [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity; c: the total number of cities you own)
[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]On the contrary, if you have abundant [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity (more than [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]25[ENDCOLOR]), you will receive [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science bonus by percentage (maximum +50%[ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output nationwide) according to the total number of cities you own. Here is the math: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]P= n/c [NEWLINE](P:the additional percentage of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science penalty caused by the number of [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity you currently have; n:the number of negative [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity; c: the total number of cities you own)
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For example, if you have [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]50[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity and own 5 cities. You will receive a bonus of +10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output (P=50/5=10). If you have [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]-50[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_ELECTRICITY] Electricity, you will receive a penalty of -10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output (P=50*(5/10)=25).

Electric power is the rate at which electrical energy is transferred by an electric circuit. The SI unit of power is the watt, one joule per second.Electric power is usually produced by electric generators, but can also be supplied by sources such as electric batteries. It is generally supplied to businesses and homes by the electric power industry through an electric power grid. Electric power is usually sold by the kilowatt hour (3.6 MJ) which is the product of power in kilowatts multiplied by running time in hours. Electric utilities measure power using an electricity meter, which keeps a running total of the electric energy delivered to a customer.

In SuperPower Mod, your people are not statistics, they will consume a certain amount of consumer product in their daily lives. As a result, Consumer Goods are very important. The amount of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods you own will affect the global [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness of your nation directly.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]1. The use of Consumer Goods: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]City population size. Larger cities will consume more [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]City level: Cities further away from your [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital will consume more [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]International Trade Units and Settlers.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]2. How to acquire Consumer Goods: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Merchant specialists in your cities will produce lots of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods, which is its main source. (+4 [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods per Merchant, upgradable by certain policies) [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Some buildings with an icon of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] will provide a small amount of Consumer Goods on their own. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]You may also acquire Consumer Goods from other civilizations by trading or allied city-states.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]3. The Global Effects of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]If the number of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods is negative (lower than [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]0[ENDCOLOR]), your people will be very unhappy due to unable to purchase their daily products and cause huge unhappiness penalty by percentage (from +5% [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness to +50% [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness) according to the total number of cities you own. Here is the math: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]P= n*(c/10) [NEWLINE](P:the additional percentage of [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] unhappiness caused by the number of negative [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods; n:the number of negative [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods; c: the total number of cities you own)
[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]On the contrary, if you have abundant [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods (more than [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]25[ENDCOLOR]), the total unhappiness of your nation will decrease by percentage (maximum -50%[ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness). What's more, you will also receive a bonus for the [ICON_GOLD] income of [ICON_TRADE] trade routes (maximum +50%, can multiply with other effects). Both positive effects are scaled according to the total number of cities you own. Here is the math: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]P= n/c [NEWLINE](P:the reduced percentage of [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness, or the additional percentage of [ICON_GOLD] Gold from [ICON_TRADE] trade routes; n:the number of [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods you currently have; c: the total number of cities you own)
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For example, if you have [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]50[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods and own 5 cities. You will receive a bonus of -10% [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness and +10% [ICON_GOLD] Gold from [ICON_TRADE] trade routes (P=50/5=10). If you have [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]-50[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_CONSUMER] Consumer Goods, you will receive a penalty of +25% [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness (P=50*(5/10)=25).

Consumer goods are goods that are ultimately consumed rather than used in the production of another good. For example, a microwave oven or a bicycle which is sold to a consumer is a final good or consumer good, whereas the components which are sold to be used in those goods are called intermediate goods.
In SuperPower Mod, the deep ocean without any resources can also be improved by digging out Natural Gas. It will provide additional [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production output of the plot.

Natural gas is a naturally occurring hydrocarbon gas mixture consisting primarily of methane, but commonly including varying amounts of other higher alkanes, and sometimes a small percentage of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, hydrogen sulfide, or helium.

Replace.Text: Coffee

Coffee is a brewed beverage prepared from the roasted seeds of several species of evergreen shrub belonging to the genus Coffea. The earliest credible evidence of either coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree appears in the middle of the 15th century, in the monasteries of Arabia. It was there that coffee seeds were first roasted and brewed, in a similar way to how it is prepared today. Eventually, through trade, coffee spread to Venetian ports in Italy, and from there, it was introduced to the rest of Europe.
Tea

Tea is an aromatic beverage commonly prepared by pouring hot water over cured leaves of the tea plant. Tea drinking likely began in China, during the Shang Dynasty, when it was initially used for medicinal purposes and combined with other herbs. It was first introduced to Portuguese priests and merchants in China during the 16th century, and later became popular in Britain during the 17th century, which eventually led to Britain competing with China's monopoly over it.
Tobacco

Tobacco is a product processed from the dried leaves of plants in the genus Nicotiana. It is used recreationally in cigars and cigarettes, snuff, pipe tobacco, chewing tobacco and flavored shisha. Many Native American tribes have traditionally gReplacen and used tobacco, with some cultivation sites in Mexico dating back to 1400-1000 B.C. Eastern North American tribes carried large amounts of tobacco in pouches as a readily accepted trade item, and often smoked it in peace pipes, either in defined sacred ceremonies or to seal a bargain. Following the arrival of the Europeans, tobacco became increasingly popular as a trade item and grew into its own industry.
Amber

Amber is fossilized tree resin, which has been appreciated for its color and natural beauty since Neolithic times. Much valued from antiquity to the present as a gemstone, amber is made into a variety of decorative objects. Amber is used as an ingredient in perfumes, as a healing agent in folk medicine, and as jewelry. Because it originates as a soft, sticky tree resin, amber sometimes contains animal and plant material as inclusions.
Jade

Jade is an ornamental stone and is the name given to two types of metamorphic rock, nephrite and jadeite. Among the earliest known jade artifacts excavated from prehistoric sites are simple ornaments with bead, button, and tubular shapes. Additionally, jade was used for adze heads, knives, and other weapons, which can be delicately shaped. As metal-working technologies became available, the beauty of jade made it valuable for ornaments and decorative objects. In Chinese history, Jade was considered the "imperial gem" and had a status-value exceeding that of gold or silver.
Olives

The olive is a species of small tree in the family Oleaceae, native to the coastal areas of the eastern Mediterranean Basin as well as northern Iraq, and northern Iran at the south of the Caspian Sea. Its fruit, also called the olive, is of major agricultural importance in the Mediterranean region as the source of olive oil. The olive has been the symbol of peace, wisdom, glory, fertility, power and purity. Olive oil has long been considered sacred, and even today, it is still used in many religious ceremonies. Over the years, the olive has been the symbol of peace, wisdom, glory, fertility, power and purity.
Perfume

Perfumes have been known to exist in some of the earliest human civilizations. Perfumery, or the art of making perfumes, began in ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt and was further refined by the Romans and Persians. The production technique of rose perfumes originated in Persia then spread through Arabia and India, and more recently into Eastern Europe. Rose oil is the essential oil extracted from the petals of various types of roses. Due to the labor-intensive production process and the low content of oil in the rose blooms, rose oil commands a very high price. Even so, it is still perhaps the most widely used essential oil in perfumery.
Coral

Coral is a branching skeleton-like structure built by small marine animals known as polyps. Red coral, also known as precious coral, is one of the most ancient of gems and has been harvested since antiquity for decorative use. It belongs to a small class of organic gemstones, which are not really stones at all, that include materials such as pearl, amber, ivory, and jet. Historically, precious coral was not only a highly prized form of ornamentation, but it was also a substance believed to be endowed with mysterious sacred properties. Along with being used as a charm, it also had many medicinal virtues attributed to it. Today, laws and organizations help protect coral reefs since their populations are threatened by overharvesting, overfishing, and climate change.
Lapis Lazuli

Lapis lazuli is a deep blue semi-precious stone that has been prized since antiquity for its intense color. It has been mined for over 6,000 years in Afghanistan and was the source of lapis for ancient Egyptian and Mesopotamian civilizations, as well as the later Greeks and Romans. In addition to the Afghan deposits, lapis lazuli can be found in other parts of the world, such as Russia, Chile, Canada, India, Italy, and the USA. Lapis lazuli takes an excellent polish and was valued for making into jewelry, carvings, vases, and other ornaments; especially in ancient Egypt. It was also ground and processed to make the most highly sought after pigment, ultramarine, which was worth more than gold. During the Renaissance, this valuable pigment was used sparingly and often reserved to color the robes of Mary and other important religious figures.
Glass

Glass has been used for centuries in windows and drinking vessels. Archaeological evidence suggests the first man made glass was in Eastern Mesopotamia and Egypt around 3500 BC and the first glass vessels were made there around 1500 BC. Syrian craftsmen invented the blow pipe in the 1st century BC, which made glass production easier, faster, and cheaper. Glass production flourished in the Roman Empire and spread from Italy to all countries under its rule. Venice was famous for its ornate glass-work, known as Venetian glass, and was the glassmaking center of the western world. Toward the end of the 13th century, the center of the Venetian glass industry moved to Murano. Some of the most important brands of glass in the world today are still produced in the historical glass factories within Murano.
Glass is only available through a Mercantile City-State.

Row.Text: Used by futuristic buildings and units. Does not spawn on the map, and must be produced by special buildings.

Nanomaterials describe, in principle, materials of which a single unit is sized (in at least one dimension) between 1 and 1000 nanometers. Materials with structure at the nanoscale often have unique optical, electronic, or mechanical properties. As such, they form an integral component of many futuristic military units and buildings. However, unlike most strategic resources, they are not found anywhere naturally, but instead must be produced by buildings such as Nanomaterial Plants, Converters, and Nucleonic Foundries.
